Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2009 04:13PM DebbyB wrote: I had my first treatment yesterday and everything went fine.  Like everyone has said the anticipation and waiting was FAR worse than the treatment.  It was a long day but had no problems.  I was actually very calm when I finally got into the room and sat in my recliner chair.  Went back today for my "shot" and so far so good!  I met a woman who was getting her shot at the same time and she also started her treatments yesterday for BC.  She was very eager to talk to someone who is going through the same thing and we will be having our next treatment at the same time, so I look forward to talking with her more.  I will let her know about this board and how very helpful and comforting it can be.  Because I was supposed to start on March 12th, which was the day after the port was put in, I'm actually glad I had some time for the port to heal.  I think having Chemo right after would have been very uncomfortable. Thank you all for the kind words and just being here.
Posts.Title: **NEW** Starting Chemo March 2009 ginagina celia088

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2009 03:59PM DebbyB wrote: After two cancelled dates to start treatments because of insurance problems, tomorrow I will finally start my chemo.  I've put on the brave face for my family but deep down I'm terrified. Even though I've read so many posts about others journey through this (which has really helped me), I don't know what I am going to face.  I've got my book, my ipod and journal ready to go with me tomorrow for the 5 hours I'm told I'll be there.  I pray every night that God will be right there helping me as well as everyone that's going through this.  I know that something positive has to come from all of this, I just don't know what it is yet.   I'm so glad there is a forum such as this that we can all connect, vent, talk, pray, whatever each other needs to help get through this.
Posts.Title: **NEW** Starting Chemo March 2009 ginagina celia088

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2009 07:54PM DebbyB wrote: You said your general practitioner wanted to do the procedure.  If it was me, I'd get a second opinion from a breast surgeon.  I had a lumpectomy performed by a breast surgeon under general anesthetic in a hospital.  I've never heard of doing this procedure in an office setting.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy and Lots of Questions please help! Runninhard BarbRocks

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2009 03:39PM DebbyB wrote: KS1, There is a wealth of information here that will be helpful to you.  I am a newbie also and will be starting my chemo treatments this Thursday.  I recently had trouble with my insurance company, only because I switched to a new company in October and was diagnosed in January.  My oncologist sent in the authorization for chemotherapy treatments on Feb. 26th.  It wasn't until March 18th that all my medical records from all my doctors were received by the insurance company to make sure my diagnosis was not pre-existing. I also learned that had I sent in a certificate of credible coverage from my prior insurance company that all the waiting would have been avoided.   On Friday, March 20th the company made the decision that I had no pre-existing conditions. The request for approval of the chemo meds would be forwarded to the nurse and I should have an answer by Monday or Tuesday.   Later that afternoon, on the 20th, I received a phone call from the nurse with the insurance company that my chemo meds were approved.   So for me, once the "new policy review" was concluded the chemo was approved very quickly. Because I called the insurance company so many times to find out what was going on, the ladies in that office all knew me and were very helpful to me in explaining their process and what was being done.  They appreciated the fact that I was nice and respectful to them and understood the stress that waiting was putting on me, so they actually did more than was required of them, which I believe got things approved quickly.  In our situation the last thing any of us wants to deal with is insurance problems!  Good Luck and I hope that all is approved very quickly for you!
Posts.Title: Insurance & chemo KS1 KS1

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2009 10:48PM DebbyB wrote: I had my last chemo treatment on July 9th and started my rads today.  It was quick and easy for me.  Went in at 7:50 a.m. and walked out at 8:05 a.m.  Will be doing 6 1/2 weeks.  Still have Herceptin treatments every 3 weeks until April 2010.
